conclusion: To determine when particles A and B are the farthest apart, analyze the areas under the velocity-time graphs for both particles.

The y-axis represents velocity (v) and the x-axis represents time (t). Particle A starts from rest and reaches its maximum velocity 2v0 at t = t0, then decelerates linearly until it stops at t = 3t0. Particle B starts from rest and accelerates linearly to reach a velocity v0 at t = 3t0.
The area under the velocity-time graph gives the displacement.
For particle A, from t = 0 to t = t0, the displacement is 1/2 * t0 * 2v0 = v0t0.
For particle A, from t = t0 to t = 3t0, the displacement is 1/2 * 2t0 * 2v0 = 2v0t0.
Total displacement for A up to t = 3t0 is v0t0 + 2v0t0 = 3v0t0.
For particle B, from t = 0 to t = 3t0, the displacement is 1/2 * 3t0 * v0 = 3/2v0t0.
The relative displacement between A and B is the difference in their displacements.
At t = 3t0, displacement of A is 3v0t0 and displacement of B is 3/2v0t0. Relative displacement is 3v0t0 - 3/2v0t0 = 3/2v0t0.
After t = 3t0, particle A stops moving, while B continues to increase its velocity until t = 5t0 and then decelerates to stop at t = 6t0.
The farthest apart occurs when the relative displacement is maximized.
The maximum relative displacement happens at t = 3t0, as after this point, B's increasing velocity reduces the gap between A and B.
Particles A and B are the farthest apart at t = 3t0.
